We're not crying, you are. The Stockholm Syndrome accusations The Stockholm Syndrome accusations Advertisement 
The idea that Beauty and the Beast is a glorified story of Stockholm Syndrome is a tale as old as time, or at least as old as Disney’s 1991 animated film. 
Live-action Beauty and the Beast star Emma is fighting back against the criticism, telling Entertainment Weekly , “Stockholm Syndrome is where a prisoner will take on the characteristics of and fall in love with the captor.” 
“Belle actively argues and disagrees with [Beast] constantly. She has none of the characteristics of someone with Stockholm Syndrome because she keeps her independence.” 
Emma did graduate from the Ivy League's Brown University, so we guess we have to believe she’s right. The "Belle" song The "Belle" song Advertisement 
We all remember the "Bonjour, Bonjour, Bonjour!" song from the original animated movie and now we can hear Emma Watson's version for the live-action remake. 
However, the 2017 version of "Belle" may be hiding one very Harry Potter Easter egg, the Huffington Post points out. 
While singing, the Disney princess asks a townsperson if he's lost something. The man responds, "I believe I have. Problem is, I can’t remember what," despite having a totally different answer in the original track. 
Neville Longbottom tells Emma's Hermione something nearly identical in Sorcerer’s Stone . Coincidence? We think not. The premiere date The premiere date Advertisement 
We’ll be able to enjoy all the Beauty ful goodness on Friday, March 17, when Beauty and the Beast hits theaters. NEXT Advertisement 
It’s a tale as old as time, and soon it’ll be a real-life tale on the big screen. 
Disney’s live-action Beauty and the Beast remake will debut in just a few weeks — and we couldn’t be more excited. 
Take a look at the gallery above to hear John Legend and Ariana Grande sing "Beauty and the Beast" and get more details on the film, like whether it's hiding a Harry Potter Easter egg.
